title: Petersen Museum's Newest Exhibit Showcases Iconic Off-Road Racers - Car and Driver

Called 'Legends of the Dirt,' it includes a classic Bronco Baja winner and possibly the craziest Suzuki hatchback of all time.

*   **There's a classic Bronco Baja winner, an Italian WRC legend, and possibly the craziest Suzuki hatchback of all time.**

While the Petersen Automotive Museum is otherwise a glittering collection of gleaming sheetmetal on polished floors, its latest exhibition is all about getting mud on your boots. Dubbed "Legends of the Dirt, the exhibit features some of the greatest off-road racing machines from the Baja 1000, King of the Hammers, and the World Rally Championship.

From the latter, we have the 1983 Lancia Rally 037, the last rear-wheel-drive car to hold its own against the onslaught of all-wheel-drive machines in WRC racing. Driven by Finn Markku Alén and Walter Röhrl (perhaps better known for his exploits racing for Audi), this car won Lancia the Constructor's title in 1983. Every winning driver since then has been in an AWD machine.

Speaking of all-wheel drive, few machines are nuttier than the 1993 Suzuki Cultus Pikes Peak Special. You may remember this subcompact hatchback as the Suzuki Swift or Pontiac Firefly (or even the Geo Metro, as it was sold here), which ordinarily had front-wheel drive and no more than 100 hp. This example has almost eight times as much.

Raced at the Pikes Peak International Hillclimb by the affable Nouhiro "Monster" Tajima—and by thousands of youngsters in _Gran Turismo 2_—this hugely winged hatchback makes its power through a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine mounted up front. And, also, a second turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine in the rear. That's a lot of motor for one little car, especially one that tips the scales at less than 2000 pounds.

The Petersen will also be featuring a number of significant off-road racing trucks, including the 1995 Herbst "Landshark." A SCORE International Class 1 desert racer, this custom-built off-roader was a game changer when it arrived on the sands in the mid-1990s, a cross between a traditional buggy-style Baja racer and the toughness of a truck.

Other Baja legends include the 1970 Bronco "Big Oly" as driven by Parnelli Jones to two consecutive Baja 1000 wins (1971 and 1972). It looks like a Bronco on the outside, but it's a custom tube chassis underneath with a partially composite body. Like any good dune racer, it loves to fly.

Other notable examples on display include the first King of the Hammers-winning Ford Bronco Ultra4, a 2010 Coleworks rock bouncer made for extreme vertical climbing, and a Global Rallycross Volkswagen Beetle GRC. Alongside these will be a collection of historically significant off-road racing motorcycles, along with displays explaining how off-road tech works.

This is the first time the Petersen has really gone big into an off-roading display, so if you're a fan of low-flying Fords taking to the skies above the Baja peninsula, you're going to want to schedule a visit. The exhibit opens on December 7 and runs right through January 2027. And they won't even make you wipe your feet before they let you in.

Brendan McAleer is a freelance writer and photographer based in North Vancouver, B.C., Canada. He grew up splitting his knuckles on British automobiles, came of age in the golden era of Japanese sport-compact performance, and began writing about cars and people in 2008. His particular interest is the intersection between humanity and machinery, whether it is the racing career of Walter Cronkite or Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki's half-century obsession with the Citroën 2CV. He has taught both of his young daughters how to shift a manual transmission and is grateful for the excuse they provide to be perpetually buying Hot Wheels.
